bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, July 16, 1897

div1.p: Lazear writes about financial issues and invites Sweitzer to join him in Massachusetts.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, July 16, 1897
div1.p:
Two letters
came from you today
one containing checks
for $150 & $10 for
which we are very
much obliged.

Mabel will write
herself. The latter
letter was written
yesterday which
looks as though the
mail service was
improving.

There is no reason
to worry about the
Nov. Co. By “con-
demnation” it simply
means that the
government has bought
bought the property
of the company. They
will probably pay
full value and
your share of th
the proceeds will
be reinvested by the
Safe Deposit Co.

It still remains
cold here. In many respects
the climate here is good but
it is often damp and foggy.
I think you would enjoy
it here for a while. and
if you get tired of Hatley it
would be nice for you to come
here. The Yankees go in for
a slim diet made up mostly
of pastry but there is a
boarding place near this
one, where the Kilhams are
at at whose landlady will
do about whatever is wanted.

I don't like to suggest your
leaving Hatley if it is satis-
factory, for you might not
like it here, but I think it
would be very nice for us all
to be here for a while before
returning to Baltimore.
